Award.AwardTitle: Underrepresented Scientist Support for Quark Matter 2017 Conference, Chicago, IL February 5-11, 2017.
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides support for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to participate in the 26th International Conference on Ultra-relativistic Collisions (Quark Matter 2017), which is designed to bring together theoretical and experimental physicists from around the world to discuss new developments in high energy heavy ion physics as well as developments in understanding strongly interacting matter at extreme conditions. The conference will provide valuable opportunities for early career scientists to present their own research and to interact with leaders in the field. This conference will be held in Chicago, Illinois February 5 - 11, 2017. The organizers of the conference will use accepted best practices to increase diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of the High Energy Nuclear Physics field is studying the properties of the primordial form of nuclear matter, termed quark-gluon plasma that is believed to have existed in the Early Universe right after the Big Bang. This primordial form of matter can now be created experimentally in the high energy nuclear collisions at two collider facilities: the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory and the Large Hadron Collider at CERN.  Experimental and theoretical studies of quark-gluon plasma improve our understanding of the phases and properties of nuclear matter and lead to greater insights on the surrounding world. The success of the scientific efforts in this field depends on wide international collaboration and timely dissemination of new physics ideas and emerging knowledge; discussion of the latest theoretical and experimental results through face-to-face interactions at scientific conferences advances both of these aspects significantly.  Quark Matter conference is among the most recognized and established series of scientific meetings of our field, and has over 30-years long history. The 26th edition of this conference (Quark Matter 2017) was organized by scientists from several U.S. universities, and Berkley and Brookhaven National Laboratories, and was held in Chicago from February 5th to 11th, 2017, featuring plenary and parallel presentations of the most significant recent results in the field. An established tradition of the Quark Matter conferences emphasizes importance of educational aspects in training the new generation of researchers. The first day of the meeting is entirely dedicated to a special program aimed at young scientists (graduate students and postdocs): with special guest lectures designed for improving their understanding of the relevant physics topics, advancing their skills in foundational scientific and data analysis techniques, improving their future career readiness for government, academic, and private sectors.  This grant provided travel support for ten young scientists from underrepresented groups, allowing them to attend the conference.
